decision.reasoning:
At a 59.5% price, the market is implying Seattle is a fairly strong Super Bowl favorite on a neutral field. For a Super Bowl matchup between two conference champions, that‚Äôs often too high unless there‚Äôs a major QB/injury mismatch or a clear team-strength gap.

From the info available:
- New England‚Äôs offense is being described in advanced terms as top-tier in explosiveness (league-best explosive creation rate cited at 13.6%), and Drake Maye has played at an ‚ÄúMVP-caliber‚Äù level per the preview notes. That generally supports NE being live to win even if Seattle‚Äôs defense is strong.
- Seattle‚Äôs best-in-NFL explosive-play differential (4.7 percentage points) and being ‚Äúthe best pass offense yet‚Äù that NE has faced in the playoffs supports Seattle as a favorite, but not automatically ~60% in a single game.
- NE‚Äôs playoff path includes multiple wins with strong defensive/low-scoring profiles (e.g., 16-3, 10-7). That kind of team can keep variance high and makes underdogs more attractive at market prices.

Net: I don‚Äôt see enough hard evidence here to justify Seattle at nearly 60%. I‚Äôd put this closer to a near coin-flip (roughly 50‚Äì55% Seattle), which creates value on NO at 40.5%. Given uncertainty and my conservative style, I‚Äôll size this small (~5% of bankroll).
